title: Elementary – Cycle 3 – Progression of Learning - Science and Technology (2009)
subject: Mathematics, Science and Technology

20D3752548FA4A90B2760F77B81F9C51.description: Describes the transformations of energy from one form to another

3E50C2B551AA418CBD655AF1E8E5C5B4.description: Explains the insulating properties of various substances (e.g. polystyrene, mineral wool, straw)

CC669F40880D422A85EA982DB34B8564.description: Names means used by human beings to limit their energy consumption (e.g. fluorescent light bulbs, timers) and to conserve energy (e.g. insulation)

886CC1B227764EBC968A30D7FF81D65B.description: Describes the behaviour of light rays (reflection, refraction)

7111BF117DD549C6AF7FD50FE07ECCDA.description: Distinguishes between substances that are thermal conductors and those that are thermal insulator

E1311C873C2B4F16890D5221CD6FF33B.description: Identifies sources of energy in his/her environment (e.g. moving water, chemical reaction in a battery, sunlight)

87AAC91DDD8C47F1B741678FB5C66366.description: Recognizes commonly used products that are potentially dangerous (safetyrelated symbols)

1738CADD5E33451A82B08AC093DA49CA.description: Associates the uses of certain household products with their properties (e.g. cleaning products remove grease, vinegar and lemon juice help preserve certain foods)

248CDE846574405D82016C4F068A0E3C.description: Explains how certain household products are made (e.g. soap, paper)1

56E35C90CCA64BE185D4D32E51D2E77F.description: Demonstrates that physical changes (e.g. deforming, breaking, grinding, phase changes) do not change the properties of matter

9BB5278E17D94E25AB5F484508EE983F.description: Recognizes that the quantity of the matter remains the same once a change has occurred (e.g. 50 ml of water in a saucer or a glass, whole piece of chalk or ground chalk, flattened piece of modelling clay or a ball of modelling clay)
